Some good news in difficult times:
A policeman patrolling the Western Wall took time out of his Tuesday evening shift to ask his long-time sweetheart to marry him...and she said Yes!

Shai Levy, a member of the Jerusalem riot squad, decided to surprise his girlfriend when he asked her to meet him at the holy prayer sight during work.

When she arrived she found herself surrounded by Levy's colleagues from the police department. Levy then proceeded to pop the big question knelt on one knee. After recovering from the shock, she said yes while the cops around her cheered!
link_name: Some good news in difficult times

Is building a succa a must for your family? Do you have special traditions in terms of how it's decorated?
 
If so, the Jerusalem Post is looking for photos showing how our reader's succas have evolved over the years. 
 
If your family has a long-standing tradition of building a succa, please send along three to four pictures showing how the span of your succa has changed over time along with a caption saying when the photo was taken and where.
 
Winning submissions will be featured in a photo gallery in our Succot supplement. 
 
To submit photos please email the editor the special magazine, Noa Amouyal at noa.amouyal@gmail.com

It's been a year since Operation Protective Edge and the fall of Givati Brigade members Liel Gidoni, Benaya Sarel and Hadar Goldin. 

Their friends in Givati wanted to do something in their memory and decided on a 3 day hike (starting yesterday) in the North of Israel. Each one of the days will be dedicated to one of the fallen soldiers.

Yesterday, about 200 friends and family joined the hike to remember the fallen.

Thank you for keeping us up to date with the latest news and for not obscuring the truth.

With Love from South Africa

Tean Gouws

The "Casino":

During the British Mandate, Bat Galim was Haifa's entertainment center. The "Casino," a landmark building on the Bat Galim promenade, housed a cafe patronized by British officers, although it was never used for gambling. It was also the center of water sports in the country, and a swimming pool was built there.

JPost.com - now faster with the news!

The Jerusalem Post is delighted to announce a new, speedier version of its website, jpost.com - Israel's leading English-language news website.

Our new system means that we are even quicker to bring you the news, views and analysis to stay on top of ever-changing events in Israel, the Middle East and the Jewish World.

With faster loading, quicker refresh rates and upgraded server functionality, you can find all the information you need in even less time.

So visit Jpost.com - keeping in the know is just seconds away!
link_name: JPost.com delighted to unveil new and improved Lifestyle section

[OPINION] It speaks volumes about a culture when a president, who by all accounts is personally honorable, is forced to apologize to an attorney-general for commenting favorably on her physical appearance, while, in the same week that same culture defends lace-trim thongs for teen girls with "Call Me" on the front and lace-back underwear with the word "Wild" on the back.

Welcome to America and its increasingly bizarre relationship with women's sexuality. http://bit.ly/JPost2311

(Pictured: Cast of Spring Breakers)
(John Kron)

[EDITORIAL] As dependable as the changing of seasons, anti-Semitism may, like the weather, fluctuate, but never does it dissipate. http://bit.ly/JPost2310

Pictured: A German anti-Semitic illustration depicting Jewish world domination circa 1893, captioned, "The entire world is the homeland of the Jews."

[OPINION] Comparisons to the Holocaust signify a worrying trend, as they undermine the uniqueness of the catastrophe of the Holocaust by insinuating that it is comparable to other world events, rather than standing out in a category all of its own. This too is a form of Holocaust-denial, one that is no less pernicious than the blatant attempts to say that it never happened. http://bit.ly/JPost2312

Let's get one thing straight: the Holocaust is not a political talking point. It was the systematic attempt by the Germans and their collaborators to erase the Jewish people from the face of the earth.

(Photo: Wikipedia Commons - Prisoners of the Wobbelin Concentration Camp shortly after liberation.)

David Berger, the weightlifter who was massacred alongside 10 other Israeli athletes by Palestinian terrorists at the 1972 Munich Olympics, will be inducted into the National Jewish Museum Sports Hall of Fame. http://bit.ly/JPost2315

[OPINION] The time has come to recognize that encouraging children to hurl stones and firebombs, as well as using them as human shields, as practiced by Hamas, cannot be described as anything but enlisting them to participate actively in hostilities and therefore a war crime. http://bit.ly/JPost2302

(Photo: Wikicommons)
The responsibility of the living. (John Kron)

[OPINION] As many as 5,000 Jews, mostly children, were hidden from the Nazis by the village of Chambon Sur Lignon, a community of mainly Protestant Christians. Their story is the story of ordinary people who displayed courage and uprightness when it was so desperately needed, and yet in such short supply. Everybody in the village was aware of what was at stake. If the Germans had discovered the Jews, the entire village would, most likely, have been wiped out. http://bit.ly/JPost2301

Photo: Jewish children in Chambon Sur Lignon. (United States Holocaust Memorial Museum)

A new photo collection offers a lesser-told narrative of the Holocaust, highlighting images of Jewish resistance, self-preservation and defiance during the Shoah, as well as postwar healing and recovery. Find photos, here: http://bit.ly/JPost2297

Would you use a hagaddah that looked something like this? If you answered 'yes,' read more about The Bronfman Haggadah, written by Edgar Bronfman and illustrated by his wife, artist Jan Aronson, here: http://bit.ly/JPost2217

The haggadah was created with progressive, liberal Jews in mind, as it interprets the Exodus story and God as metaphors rather than historical fact. In the text, God can be understood through sounds and images in the natural world. Further to this, The Brofman Haggadah honors "Miriam's Cup" beside the traditional Prophet Elijah's glass, borrows from contemporary civil rights struggles, and welcomes interfaith families.

[BLOG] Tonight, we celebrate Passover by conducting the Seder, a ritual that revolves around a core text known as the Haggadah.  The name "Haggadah" comes from the concept of Vihigaditah, which appears in the book of Exodus. The verse is usually interpreted as, "And you shall tell your child."  
 
The great Jewish, medieval philosopher, Maimonides, famously asks whether one is obliged to read the Haggadah if alone when conducting the Seder.  He answers that the Commandment still prevails in that circumstance. The explicit reason is that there is an inherent value derived from articulating the story, but the implicit rationale for this Maimonidean ruling is that there is a child present even in that scenario. A child exists within each adult. http://bit.ly/JPost2215
The modern day Passover dilemma ... Spoiled for choice. (John Kron)

[BLOG] Any African migrant arrested for a crime of brutality – a rape, an aggravated assault and robbery – becomes part of a far larger context. He becomes a central player in the worsening crime rate in south Tel Aviv and the government's failure to deal with the illegal migration problem. This creates a situation where one writes a headline or subheading mentioning the assailant's nationality, at times with the full knowledge that such a clarification would probably not be made in the United States or Europe, where a headline reading "Mexican rapes teen in apartment break-in" would be seen as racist and have little chance of seeing the light of day. http://bit.ly/JPost2900

The core characteristic of anti-Semitism is the assertion that everything the Jews do is wrong, and everything that is wrong is done by the Jews. Nothing the Jew or the Jew among nations does can be praised, because its purpose is always to "manipulate," to "conceal," to "divert attention away from" or to "distort" the evil that inheres in all Jewish actions and inactions. Today's selection concerns the the man who may succeed Pope Benedict XVI, Cardinal Andres Rodriguez Maradiaga: "To put it most simply, Rodriguez Maradiaga is an out and out Jew-hater.  He has said that "the Jews" are to blame for the scandal surrounding the sexual misconduct of priests toward young parishioners!  The Jews?  How did Rodriguez Maradiaga ever come up with this hair-brained idea?  Here is his "logic." He begins by asserting that the Vatican is anti-Israel and pro-Palestinian (as he says it should be).  It follows, therefore, that "The Jews" had to get even with the Catholic Church, while at the same time deflecting attention away from Israeli injustices against the Palestinians.  The Jews managed to do this by arranging for the media—which he says they control—to give disproportionate attention on the Vatican sex scandal. " Read more, here: http://bit.ly/JPostPremium

[OPINION] "Paradoxically, often the grand extinguisher of a woman's libido is her own husband. Financial instability, moral uncertainty, consumerism and shifts in the essence of masculinity have led husbands to exchange the untamed sensuality of a woman for the predictable safety of a functional wife. In an attempt to maintain control over an uncontrollable world, the husband's need for order, routine and a sense of competence has been displaced onto his wife and he has reduced and contained her in an attempt to forestall his fear of confusion and inferiority. The result is a wife who meets his basic functional needs, but whom he may find uninteresting." http://bit.ly/JPost1717

" [The Jewish PR problem] is not a problem of not having enough messengers. I'd even say there are too many... Think how many Jewish/Israel causes and organizations there are. It's a virtual alphabet soup. From AJC, ADL and AIPAC all the way to the ZOA with every initial in between from Hadassah, Hillel, Israel21c, J Street, JNF, etc.

[EDITORIAL] The two popes' trips to Israel – John Paul's in 2000 and Benedict's in 2009 – illustrate [the difference in their respective approaches towards Judaism]. While John Paul's visit was widely regarded as a landmark event in relations between the Catholic Church and the Jewish people, Benedict left the impression among many Israelis that more could have been said and done to assuage suspicions regarding his German background – including a period during World War II when he was obligated to join the Hitler Youth – his position on the Holocaust and his theological approach to the Jewish people. http://bit.ly/JPost1686

[BLOG] In his JPost blog, former mayor of New York Ed Koch shares an exchange between himself and British Prime Minister, David Cameron, on Israel's policy of settlement. http://bit.ly/JPost1430

[From Cameron] "We firmly believe that the people of Israel have a right to live peacefully and free from terror. But we also believe that the only sustainable way to achieve this is through a negotiated two-state solution. As friends of Israel, it is important we do whatever we can to reach that ultimate objective: two states, living side by side, in peace. We ask Israel to stop building settlements because they are illegal under international law, an obstacle to peace and make a two-state solution, with Jerusalem as a shared capital, harder to achieve. They are, ultimately, not in Israel's long-term interests. Simply building a fortress without a negotiated agreement with the Palestinians cannot deliver lasting security for Israel."

[BLOG] The heart of the matter [in Mali] is the problem of dealing militarily with irregular forces, i.e., fighters that are not the disciplined armies of an established government, which stop fighting when their government cries "uncle." Irregulars pursue their religious or political purposes with munitions and money received either openly or on the sly from friendly governments, and have shown an impressive capacity to regroup even after suffering serious losses. They are beholden to no government that can control them, and order them to stop fighting. http://bit.ly/JPostBlog1

Pictures have them standing naked, after the SS removed their clothing, and they are not even trying to cover up in front of the German soldiers. Here was a rabbi finding fault with Jewish women who were about to be murdered along with their children, which just goes to show that the belief that suffering results from sin can lead to shocking anti-Semitism.

He's a veteran American oleh with "right of center security views" and a strong belief in "voting for large parties."

Netanyahu and Likud-Beytenu seem like the obvious choice - except for one thing: Netanyahu's irresponsible "increased government spending on social issues," which are directly to blame for bringing him to near bancruptcy. "But I can't. Not when mainstream politicians make racist statements and are tolerated. Not when price tag attacks occur with alarming regularity without being investigated aggressively or raising outrage among the general population." 

(Photo: Ronen Zvulun/Reuters)

[OPINION] To better understand the intractable nature of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict one needs to keep in mind that at least with regard to the Middle East, this Western assumption of rationality is subject to certain limitations. Rationality means to mainly focus on the near future and consider how the greatest prosperity and good for all can be attained. But can we say that this describes leaders in the Middle East? [OPINION] http://bit.ly/JPost1394 For me, though, what's been hardest about making aliya has been watching the worldview on which I was raised crash and break like a ship washed violently against a forbidding shore. I was raised in one of those (then-) classic American Jewish suburban families. My parents taught their kids that most people were reasonable and that all conflicts were solvable. When it came to the Middle East, the prescription for resolution of the conflict was clear – we would give land, and we would get peace. The only question was when.

We were not the only ones who believed that, of course. A significant portion of Israeli society believed the same thing – until the Palestinian Terror War (mistakenly called the second intifada) – that is. http://bit.ly/JPost1394

(Photo: Ahmed Jadallah/Reuters)

Hear our voices: We, the Jewish mothers, sisters and daughters are trying, sometimes against all Western odds, to maintain meaningful, spiritual Jewish lives – to bestow upon our children Jewish values, to play positive, prominent roles in society despite the aggression we are facing in the ever-fanaticizing contemporary landscape... What you see here may look like an ordinary water color, but in reality, it is a painting made from ashes collected at a Nazi concentration camp in Poland. The painting was done by the controversial Swedish artist, Carl Michael von Hausswolff, who collected the ashes in the '80s and used them in 2010. 

Read here for details on the investigation that Polish prosecutors have opened against von Hausswolff, who claim the artist violated the Polish law against theft from graves or other places of rest: http://bit.ly/JPost1383

If you suffer from phytobezoars, gastrointestinal clogs composed of indigestible materials from fruits and veggies - drinking Coke may be your best - and safest - way of getting rid of them.

[OPINION] "For the unaware or delusional: Netanyahu will remain Israel's prime minister." http://bit.ly/JPost1371

However, the question remains: What coalition Netanyahu will choose to form. If he forms a centrist coalition with Yesh Atid and Tzipi Livni, "he will find himself heading a government increasingly focused on mending the secular-religious divide, one which would by and large support settlement construction while leaving the door open to negotiations with the Palestinians." If he chooses to form a coalition with the haredi and far-right parties, "the coalition would undoubtedly try to downplay the Israeli-Palestinian track, foster settlement construction – at least in the main blocs – and push for a replacement of the Tal Law that would see haredim continue to study in yeshivas in lieu of IDF service."

[OPINION] As is often the case with government funding programs, US financial aid to the Middle East has good intentions with bad results. http://bit.ly/JPost1364

Most fundamentally, US military aid to the Middle East harms Israeli and regional interests by fueling an arms race that threatens to spiral out of control. Recent Israeli-produced estimates reveal that for every dollar in US aid received by Egypt, Israel must spend between $1.60 and $2.10 to maintain its qualitative military edge.Since Israel is usually granted $1.50 for every $1 in aid to Egypt, each American dollar given to Egypt costs Israel between 10 and 64 cents out of its own pocket.

(Photo: US Defense Secretary Leon Panetta and Israeli Minister of Defense Ehud Barak visiting an Iron Dome site, by Amir Cohen/Reuters)

Call for photos: Winter storms across Israel

Attention all JPost readers and fans! 

 

We're looking for photos of the winter storms that have been hitting Israel this past week. Whether you're in the North, South or Center, whether you're using a smartphone, a point-and-shoot or an SLR, we want your photos of flooded streets and malls, fallen trees and bundled-up pedestrians, rain boots and umbrellas, and even puddles. 

 

We'll use your photos in stories and galleries on our website and associated pages.

 

Please email all photos to Zohar@JPost.com. Note: By emailing your photos to the email address Zohar@jpost.com, you grant 'The Jerusalem Post' permanent licence to use your photos. 

 

Thank you

[ANALYSIS] What does the forecast look like for Jews in Tunisia? http://bit.ly/JPost1342

Now that the Ennahada party, an offshoot of the Muslim Brotherhood, is ruling Tunisia, an upswing in anti-Semitism and anti-Zionism has been observed in the North African country. Incidences include: The attempt to criminalize normalized relations with Israel; an marked rise in physical and verbal violence against Jews; and a pronounced rise in radical Islamic leaders openly sermonizing against Jews, with one Imam publicly begging in a broadly-televised sermon for Allah to "make the men and women sterile."

Thanks to the harassment from police, health professionals and society itself, not many women come forward to report rape and sexual assault. Who says we don't live in an age of miracles? 53 new immigrants from the Bnei Menashe community of northeastern India landed at Ben-Gurion Airport last monday. http://bit.ly/JPost1267

The Bnei Menashe are descendants of the tribe of Manasseh, one of the Ten Lost Tribes of Israel exiled by the Assyrian empire in 722 BCE. Despite being cut off from the rest of the Jewish people for so many centuries, the Bnei Menashe remained dedicated to their heritage, stubbornly cleaving to the faith of their forefathers. They observed the Sabbath and kept kosher, celebrated the festivals, practiced the sacrificial rites and even argued a lot among themselves, just as Jews have done since time immemorial.

(Photo: Reuters/Gil Cohen Magen)

Pre-state Israel photo of the week: Tourists visit Soloman's Quarry circa 1910. http://bit.ly/JPost710

Soloman's quarry is an an enormous cavern beneath the Old City of Jerusalem, not far from the Damascus Gate, one of the largest man-made caves in Israel.  King Herod (circa 50 BCE) is believed to have quarried stone from here for building his massive expansion of the Second Temple, including what we call today the Western Wall.

JPost photo of the day: An ultra-Orthodox Jewish man holds a chicken and performs the Kaparot ritual in the religious neighborhood of Mea She'arim in Jerusalem. 

Kaparot is an ancient Yom Kippur ritual, whereby one transfers one's sins from the past year onto the chicken. The chicken is later slaughtered as a symbolic expression of atonement and then given to charity. The ritual is performed before the Day of Atonement, Yom Kippur, the holiest day in the Jewish year. 

(Photo: Marc Israel Sellem/The Jerusalem Post)

JPost photo of the day: Shofars are manufactured at the BarSheshet-Ribak Shofar factory. The business is a merger of two shofar-producing families, the Ribaks who made aliya to Israel from Poland in 1927, and the BarSheshet family who made aliya from Morocco in the 1940s. By 1980's the two families went from being competitors in the shofar business to partners.

An insightful, tempered response from Nariman Julani, mother of Jamal Julani, the Palestinian boy who was nearly beaten to death in Jerusalem this week by a mob of Jewish teenagers. "I really pity them. And I pity their mothers. Who could be proud of a child who does a thing like this? As they grow up, they will probably be more ashamed and regret what they did. They'll go to jail, and it is their futures which will be ruined, not my son's. Instead of learning, they'll be in prison. Jamal became famous for a terrible attack that he did nothing to provoke, but these young people will be infamous."

Two JPost columnists, two different opinions. The subject: Romney VP pick Paul Ryan.

Writer Doublas Bloomfield argues that Jewish voters, "with their strong affinity for programs serving the needy and the elderly, could be the first to punch the "no sale" button on the Romney-Ryan ticket" and vote Democrat. (http://bit.ly/JPost425) 

Writer Michael Freund, on the other hand, points to Ryan's strong pro-Israel record and argues, "The possibility that Paul Ryan might very well be the next vice president of the United States is one that should excite and energize American Jews... For the sake of Israel and its future, it behooves American Jews to cross party lines in this election and cast their ballot for the Republicans." (http://bit.ly/JPost424).

Who do you agree with?

While Nefesh B'Nefesh ceremonies are a hallmark of many North American olim's aliyot to Israel, what some find moving aren't necessarily the animated speeches and sights of politicians in attendance, the abundance of Israeli flags and impassioned dancing. It's no wonder," writes JPost travel writer Wayne Stiles, "that many believe the Garden Tomb to be the tomb of Jesus. Like the tomb described in the gospel accounts, the Garden Tomb lay outside the city walls and along a road. It is hewn out of the stone and has a rolling stone entrance. A garden surrounds it." Raoul Wallenberg was a Swedish diplomat, responsible for saving up to an estimated 100 thousand Hungarian Jews during the Holocaust. In 1945, Wallenberg was detained by Soviet authorities, and that was the last confirmed siting of the famed humanitarian. Some reports say he died in a Soviet prison in 1947, while others site sources that place him at that very prison in 1971. Yet others report sitings of Wallenberg dating as late as 1981. Now, in a final bid to locate the whereabouts of Wallenberg, the International Raoul Wallenberg Foundation is offering 500,000 euros as a reward to information leading to such a discovery. READ the full story, here: http://bit.ly/JPost389

(Photo: Left, Wikicommons; right: Reuters)

Can you spot the difference between this Jerusalem-based Egged bus advertisement and (Jerusalem) bus advertisements of the past 8 years? The answer:  Women. Women's faces haven't graced Jerusalem bus ads in almost a decade. Why? Because bus companies feared that Orthodox Jews would vandalize busses featuring women. Well, that's all going to change after the Yerushalmim movement, a movement that promotes pluralism and equality in Jerusalem, petitioned the High Court to force bus companies to accept advertisements featuring women. This advertisement reads: "Women of Jerusalem, nice to meet you--because Jerusalem belongs to all of us." More on the movement's achievement, here: http://bit.ly/JPost369

Ever heard of 'forced molting?' Forced molting is a practice whereby farmers starve hens for 10-14 days in order to increase egg production. Effective January 1st, the Knesset has "called foul" and outlawed the practice, as well as required farmers to nearly double the cage sizes for chickens. More on the story, here: http://bit.ly/JPost298

As promising young athlete in 1972, Shahar Ayalon was awarded the honor of attending the Munich Olympics alongside the Israeli Olympic team. There, he and the other lucky youngsters formed close relationships with their adult counterparts, their rolemodels and idols, only to accompany their coffins back to Israel. After the games, Ayalon did not follow the course that was expected of him prior to the games and pursue his athletic career. Instead he joined the Israel Police's elite counter-terrorism unit in 1977. His story is incredible: http://bit.ly/JPost235

(Photo: Fire and Rescue Service)

A surprise moment of silence at "a ceremony that nobody knew about or paid attention to" for the 11 Israeli victims of the Munich Massacre, unsurprisingly did not satisfy the Israeli public and the late athletes' widows, who had been campaigning for a moment of silence at the opening ceremony.
 
One widow called it "shameful," while another explained that,"this is not the right solution, to hold some ceremony in front of 30 or 40 people. We asked for a moment of silence at the opening ceremony not for someone to mumble something in front of a few dozen people." Full story on the ceremony and the reactions: http://bit.ly/JPost230

Pictured here: The moment of silence. (Reuters/Toby Melville)
The good news. (Ronny Gordon)

"Munich was like a playground compared to this," says a the head of the Israeli delegation to London, referring to security measures that Israeli authorities have put into place for their Olympians, which include housing them in a closed-off section of the Olympic village, separated from other athletes. 

On the 40th anniversary of the Munich Massacre, at the heels of the Bulgaria terror attack, does Israel have especially well-founded reasons to worry? Exclusive JPost editorial on Israeli concerns ahead of the 2012 London Olympics, here: http://bit.ly/JPost221

Last week, Nazi collaborator Laszlo Csatary (95) was arrested and charged with war crimes. Now, ranks of cyber neo-Nazis have rallied together to support their comrade. How? By offering cash incentives for information on the protesters who called for Csatary's arrest. Full story: http://bit.ly/JPost216

Pictured here: Csatary at the prosecution building in Budapest, where he was charged with war crimes related to the deportation of thousands of Jews to Auschwitz during World War II. (Reuters/Laszlo Balogh)

This week in history, 1887: Polish Jew, Ludwig Lazarus Zamenhof, publishes the first guide to Esperanto, the Zamenhof created to fascilate international communication--and thereby promote peace and break down barriers between people. The Esperanto anthem: 'Hostile barriers between peoples, fall, fall, it is time! The whole of humanity must come together as one family.'  More on the origins and founder of Esperanto: http://bit.ly/JPost212

Today marks the 1878 birthday of the famous educator, writer and Polish-Jewish orphanage operator Janusz Korczak. This year also marks the 70th anniversary of the deporatation of Janusz together with the children under his care to Treblinka, where most were murdered at the hands of the Nazis; as well as the 100th anniversary of the founding of Janusz's orphanage on Warsaw's Krochmalna Street.

What has the Polish parliament done to commemorate these dates and anniversary? The answers and more history here: http://bit.ly/JPost205

Pictured here: Ein Charod, Mandatory Palestine, Janusz Korczak (in the middle) with his children, on their first visit to Mandatory Palestine, 1934. (Yad Vashem photo archives)

While desperation may not love company, it seems to attract its share, as evidenced by a series of copy-cat self-immolations witnessed across Israel. "It [Moshe Silman's self-immolation] has sparked a chain reaction," says Welfare Ministry director-general Nachum Itzkovitz. "We are trying to stop it, but it is like when there is a wave of suicides, there are always going to be people in similar desperate situations who feel that no one is listening to them and who try to emulate an extreme act." While Itzkovitz's comparison may have been intended to be illustrative in nature, has the social protest movement taken on this dark edge? http://bit.ly/JPost181

Lou Lenert (91), a US fighter pilot who helped defend a fledgling Israel after WWII, recalls a day in 1948: "It was 4 pm and a jeep rushes in with Shimon Avidan, commander of the Givati Brigade. He heard we had airplanes and said that six miles from where we were near Ashdod, there were 15,000 Egyptian soldiers and 500 vehicles and tanks stopped because Givati had blown up a bridge. But if we didn't stop them that night they would fix the bridge and be in Tel Aviv the next morning – and there would be no Israel." For more on this amazing story: http://bit.ly/JPost164

You tell us: Is Moshe Silman, the man who set himself on fire two nights ago at Tel Aviv's J14 protest, a symbol of the state's failure to provide an adequate social net? This week in history: On July 16, 1897, the father of Zionism, Theodor Herzl, publishes his article "Protest Rabbiner" (Protest Rabbis), marking the beginnings of the very contemporary debate between Zionism and Orthodox Judaism. The intricacies of the argument between Herzl and the rabbis are particularly fascinating, with the rabbis stating that 'the Jews comprise a separate community solely with respect to religion,' and emphasizing that German Jewry harbors patriotism toward the country in which they live. They argue in favor of assimilation and opine that the quest for a Zionist state impedes this goal. Herzl counters this claim by asserting 'that no one belongs to their homeland, but rather their homeland belongs to them and people must show their love for their nation through sacrifice rather than empty platitudes.' For more history: http://bit.ly/JPost157

After being beaten within an inch of his life, Morad, a 17 year old Arab boy, spent eleven days in a hospital; although he recovered from his injuries, he suffered severe PTSD and refused to speak. status_message: Today, former Prime Minister Yizthak Shamir is laid to rest at Mt. Herzl, beside Israeli leaders Yitzhak Rabin, Golda Meir, Levi Eshkol, among others. How should we understand the legacy of the late Israeli leader? Should we consider his involvement with the radical Zionist Stern Group in pre-state Israel, the murder of his father and sister at the hands of their Polish neighbors, his lifelong love for his late wife Shulamit, his service in the Mossad, his hard-line, right-wing convictions, or the fact that he suspected those convictions to form a unity-government with Shimon Peres and emerge as the first Israeli leader to negotiate directly with the Palestinians? Or should we simply remember him for his love for the Jewish people and the land of Israel? (Photo: GPO)

Media Literacy 101: To what extent do Israeli media outlets mistranslate Hebrew for the sake of sensationalizing the news?

"One example [of mistranslated Hebrew] is how Haaretz selectively translated Interior Minister Eli Yishai's words in a Ma'ariv interview to make him sound racist. The story's sub-headline reads: "Interior Minister says migrants do not recognize that Israel 'belongs to the white man.'" However, the quotation is partial. As the original Hebrew has it, the quote really is: "Most of the people coming here are Muslims who think the land doesn't belong to us at all, to the white man. A number of them have said that openly on television."

Yishai was quoting what the illegal immigrants had said, claiming that this was their opinion, that Israel doesn't belong to the "white man," but Haaretz in English implanted a racist spin to his words."
Work hazards. (Ronny Gordon)

Meet Dustin, a green sea turtle who was found at sea six months ago, floating bottom up, pictured here receiving a wakeup injection following surgery. Rehovot veterinarian Tzahi Eisenberg operated on Dustin to alleviate intestinal blockages and trapped air that may have been the cause of his loss of balance. Only time will tell if Dustin will need additional operations. (Picture: Reuters/Nir Elias)

Like our page and connect with The Jerusalem Post's staff reporters and editors to receive news, analysis, opinions, and engage in conversation about life in Israel and the Jewish world.

For more than 80 years, The Jerusalem Post has been the world's number one source of news and information in English from Israel. Now with social media, our Facebook community offers you the chance to interact with us, hear our news and views and share your ideas too.

We value thoughtful and respectful comments and will not allow personal attacks, obscenity, or profanity.
